data.text: Bicycle Wheel Rim Failure from Disc Brakes?

Hi everyone, I have a problem with the rear wheel of my bike. (See the photo). I've never seen this before, although the bike shop says that it's typical of disc braked wheels!! I'm interested in any experience you may have with this type of failure. The wheel is 3.5 yrs old, several thousand miles on it, with approx 150 per week since Feb this year. For ref - the bike is a Specialized Sequoia. Also, I have been in contact with Specialized and they have been both helpful and generous. Thanks in advance.

I have seen stress marks at the rim where the spoke attaches, but never cracked through like that. However, given the age and miles, I'm going to venture to say you got your money's worth out of that wheel.

data.text: So yeah, a disc brake is going to transfer energy/stress to the rim via the spokes (and a rim brake is going to wear the sidewall of the rim). BUT, if it's only a single spoke then that particular one was probably over-tensioned relative to the others therefore taking up more of the braking stress. Should it have happened after only that many miles - NO. But, stock bikes with stock (especially lower tier like the "no name wheels you have) components are going to have more failures. Key to longevity is periodic maintenance (just like a car), and for a bike, spoke tension is one of the most critical ones. But, for its price point and not knowing what kind of riding conditions, including for example your weight, you were subjecting it to you may have done "ok".

data.text: Yep, that's pull through. I had 2 sets of 3T wheels (the second being warranty) on my road bike that cracked at multiple spokes at around 12 months. Best guess is that was one over-tensioned spoke (either very gradually over lots of use or poor truing/repair). I have never heard of it being any more likely on disc wheels. It's all about proper tension distribution. Well built (ideally hand) with the right components typically have minimal issues.
